head.title: Willie and Davie. A Pastoral.11 First published in Poetical Essays (1788), pp. 205-208.

div1.head: Willie.22 Pastoral shepherd and speaker in Spenser’s The Shepheardes Calender (1579).

lg.l: Ah Davie,33 Pastoral shepherd; one of the eleven speakers in Spenser’s The Shepheardes Calender (1579). sure thy ruefu’ looks declare,
Thy mind o’er-burden’d wi’ a lade of care,
Shake aff that melancholy, blithe appear,
The winter’s past, and what hae we to fear?
For hark! the birds, on ilka hawthorn, sing,
And smiling nature hails the welcome spring.
Na, nature first shall change her course anew,
The bent44 Coarse grass of a reedy character. forget to laugh in morning dew,
The birds nae mair the spring’s approaching hail,
And mournfu’ shepherds winter’s loss bewail;
The wily tod grow tame and seek the fold,
And wi’ the harmless lambkin dalliance hold,
Clear streams retard their course and backward turn,
Ere I forget my griefs, and cease to mourn.
Ah hapless lad! thou ever tauks of ill,
Wha bodes misfortunes will be luckless still,
What sad disaster has befa’n thee now,

Is Luath55 Cuchullin’s celebrated dog in Macpherson’s Ossianic poems. Burns adopted the name “after some dog in Highland Sang” for his ploughman’s collie in “The Twa Dogs.” See Kinsley, Burns: Complete Poems and Songs (Oxford: Oxford UP, 1969), pp. 110-116. dead, has Maggie66 This old song etc.: these comments, from Burns's annotations in the Interleaved Scots Musical Museum, written for Burns's friend Robert Riddell, were first printed in Robert Cromek's Select Scotish Songs (1810), vol. 1, p. 93: see Davidson Cook, Annotations of Scottish Songs by Burns (Dumfries: Robert Dinwiddie, 1922), p. 13. broke her vow.
Far greater ills oblige me to complain,
Than loss of tykes or ony maid’s disdain;
Weil is it kend, nae shepherd on the lee,
Cares less for love, or womankind than me.
But joy’s forsaken, these deserted plains,
Where nought but languid melancholy reigns,
Nae mair shall music wake the sprightly morn,
Nor shepherd lasses dance beneath the thorn,
Nae mair shall bands of jolly swains repair,
To haud gay revels, on the banks of Ayr,77 The river Ayr runs through the town of Ayr two miles north of Robert Burns's birthplace in Alloway.
Nor flute, nor aiten88 adj. oaten. pipe’s melodious sound,
At setting day the cavern’d banks rebound,
Nor tunefu’ Muses haunt the vocal shore,

For there shall Robin’s reed99 “O a’ ye bard on bonie Doon! / An wha’ on Ayr your canters tune! / Come, join the melancholious croon / O’ robin’s reed! / His heart will never get aboon— / His Mailie’s dead!”: Robert Burns, Poor Mailie’s Elegy (1783), lines 42-50. be heard no more.
Had he, in early youth and beauty’s bloom,
Descended to the mansions of the tomb,
Then might ye greet, and shaw a friend’s despair,
And mournfu’ sangs, and elegies prepare;
But tell me, Davie, why should ye be sad,
That fortune favours the deserving lad,
Our praise through Albion’s spacious Isle1010 I.e., Britian. shall ring,

And courtly dames of Coila’s shepherds1111 Embodiment of the lands of Kyle in Ayrshire and muse of Robert Burns: “Of these am I—Coila my name: / And this district as mine I claim,”: “The Vision,” lines 199-200. See Kinsley, Burns: Complete Poems and Songs (Oxford: Oxford UP, 1969), p. 88. sing.
I yield, dear Willie, now I maun submit;
My grief’s o’ercome, by thy superior wit;
But friendship and the love to him I bore,
Make me his absence day by day deplore.
Nae shepherd lad, that ever trode the mead,
Cou’d, wi’ sic skilfu’ hand essay the reed.
Nane e’er was fit to entertain sae well,
As ilka lad and ilka lass can tell,
Wha sat in crowds beneath yon spreading tree,
To hear his tales, for mony a tale had he:
But I will see him soon, though I should sell
My fatted pet, distinguish’d by the bell,
To buy a bonnet, and apparel meet,
To wauk, wi’ Robin, through Edina’s1212 Edinburgh. street.
Nor shall ye, Davie, tak the road alone,
My Sunday’s coat and bonnet I’ll put on,
My mirlie1313 adj. speckled. stockings, which my mither made,
And wrap me in my Caledonian1414 Scottish; Caledonia: literary name and Latin term for Scotland. plaid,
There ance again, our com’rade swain embrace,
And see the wonders of that unco1515 adj. unknown, unfamiliar, strange. place;
But come, behold this bonny woodbine bow’r,
A shelter frae the sun’s meridian pow’r;
Here let us lean, and in some hamart1616 adj. home-made, home-grown. lays,
Not mourn his absence, but record his praise;
And see this wallet plentifully stor’d,
Wi’ dainty fare, may please the nicest Lord,
This crystal well will cauler draughts supply,
And then we’ll carol when our dinner’s by.
